abstract.p: Metabolic reprogramming and signaling are key orchestrators of T cell immunity. Recent studies have illustrated important roles for intracellular organelles, especially mitochondria and lysosomes, in enforcing T cell metabolism and signaling in response to various extracellular cues. As such, mitochondrial and lysosomal function contributes to adaptive immunity by regulating T cell activation, differentiation, and functional adaptation. In this Review, we discuss how the interplay between organelle biology and metabolism instructs T cell-mediated immunity, with a particular focus on mitochondria and lysosomes. We also summarize how mitochondria and lysosomes, or their crosstalk with other organelles, orchestrate downstream signaling processes and functional reprogramming of T cells. We conclude with a discussion of the pathophysiological outcomes associated with dysregulation of these organelles.

sec.title: Mitochondria and lysosomes are metabolic hubs in T cells
sec.p: T cells are an essential component of adaptive immunity, necessary for defense against pathogens and cancer. Conventional αβ T cells are comprised of two major subsets: CD4+ T cells that use specific effector functions to combat intracellular or extracellular pathogens or support the activation of humoral responses; and CD8+ T cells that eliminate pathogens or malignant cells via cytokine secretion or release of cytotoxic granules [1]. A CD4+ T cell subpopulation called regulatory T cells (Tregs) exerts immune suppressive function to circumvent T cell-mediated autoimmunity or immunopathology [1]. In the thymus and periphery, T cells receive multiple instructive signals that underlie their development, activation, and differentiation [1]. Among them, cellular metabolism and nutrient uptake, together with metabolic signaling events, are crucial regulators of T cell biology [1,2]. Therefore, discovering the driver signals and mechanisms of T cell immunometabolism (see Glossary) holds therapeutic potential for improving disease outcomes related to infection, autoimmunity, or cancer.

Intracellular organelles, especially mitochondria and lysosomes, orchestrate metabolic rewiring in T cells. Mitochondria facilitate oxidative metabolism for energy (ATP) production and generation of biosynthetic intermediates, including those essential for nucleotide and lipid synthesis. Moreover, mitochondria play critical roles in redox balance and serve as a central node for crosstalk between the endoplasmic reticulum, nucleus, and peroxisomes, thereby impacting T cell metabolism [3]. The bioenergetic and biosynthetic functions of mitochondria are instructed by signaling and nutrient cues that tune mitochondrial biogenesis and turnover, as well as mitochondrial dynamics [4]. Lysosomes mediate macromolecule recycling and clearance of damaged organelles, which support energetic needs during nutrient stress to maintain cellular fitness [5]. To facilitate these functions, lysosomes fuse with autophagosomes and multivesicular bodies, and also lysosomes coordinate intracellular waste disposal via exocytosis [6]. Furthermore, mitochondria and lysosomes function as metabolic signaling hubs [3,6], which support metabolic and functional adaptation in T cells. Mitochondria are also at the interface of multiple cell death pathways and coordinate with lysosomes to regulate certain cell death mechanisms, such as ferroptosis, thereby contributing to the modulation of T cell-mediated immunity [7]. Therefore, mitochondria and lysosomes orchestrate T cell metabolism via effects on metabolic rewiring, organelle crosstalk, and signaling (Figure 1, Key figure).

In this Review, we discuss mitochondria- and lysosome-directed metabolism in regulating T cell fate and function, with a primary focus on conventional αβ T cells in mouse models (unless otherwise stated). We also describe mechanisms of organelle signaling and communication in T cell functional adaptation. Finally, the impact of dysregulated mitochondrial and lysosomal function on disease development is discussed, with a particular focus on autoimmunity, infectious disease, and cancer.

sec.title: Mitochondrial metabolism and fitness in T cell function
sec.p: Mitochondrial metabolism is dynamically rewired during thymocyte development or upon mature T cell activation, and it promotes biosynthesis and energy production essential for quiescence exit and proliferation [2]. Consequently, mitochondrial metabolism shapes the fate decisions and function of developing and mature T cells as discussed in the following section.

sec.title: Mitochondria in T cell development, activation, and differentiation
sec.p: Thymocytes exhibit developmental stage-specific alterations in mitochondrial and glycolytic metabolism (Figure 2A), and the balance between mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS) and glycolysis supports the lineage commitment of T cells. For example, glycolytic programming at the double-negative 3 (DN3) stage orchestrates αβ over γδ T cell development (mediated by mTORC1–MYC signaling) [8], with glycolysis and OXPHOS also contributing to IFN-γ+ and IL-17+ γδ T cell generation, respectively [9]. Mitochondrial oxidation of pyruvate (mediated by mitochondrial pyruvate carrier; MPC1) shapes αβ T cell maturation at multiple stages [β-selection, immature single-positive (ISP)-to-double-positive (DP) transition, and positive selection] of development [10]. Mechanistically, Opa1 (mediates inner mitochondrial membrane fusion and cristae integrity) supports the metabolic quiescence of DN3 thymocytes [11], while DP and single-positive (SP) thymocytes increase Drp1-mediated mitochondrial fission to facilitate thymic egress and peripheral expansion [12,13]. Altogether, mitochondrial metabolism plays important roles in thymocyte development.

In mature T cells in the periphery, immune signals (e.g., cognate antigen–T cell receptor (TCR), co-stimulation) and nutrients (e.g., amino acids) support mitochondrial biogenesis and function [2], including one-carbon metabolism [14,15] and ATP generation via the electron transport chain (ETC) [15,16]. Inhibition of the one-carbon metabolism enzyme MTHFD2 impairs CD4+ T cell activation and effector differentiation [17]. The ETC is also required for naïve CD4+ T cell quiescence exit and proliferation (Figure 2B) [15,18–20]. ETC complex I supports the activation and proliferation of CD4+ T cells, while complex II facilitates TH1 and TH17 effector function [21]. Besides decreasing mitochondrial fusion, Opa1 ablation reduces mitochondrial respiration and enhances glutamine oxidation to impair TH17 effector function and RORγt expression via generation of metabolites that promote transcriptional remodeling [22], indicating that mitochondrial dynamics-related proteins can influence cellular functions at multiple levels. Therefore, mitochondria orchestrate CD4+ T cell responses.

Mitochondria also control CD8+ T cell fate and function (Figure 2C). Mitochondrial membrane potential (MMP) maintains ETC efficiency and ATP production downstream of the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle. Specifically, CD8+ T cells with higher MMP have increased effector function [23] and migratory capacity [24] that correspond with increased mTORC1-driven glycolysis and reactive oxygen species (ROS) production [23], whereas those with lower MMP have enhanced self-renewal and survival, decreased mTORC1 activity and ROS production, and increased OXPHOS capacity [23]. Enhancing MMP via ablation of MCJ (a negative regulator of ETC complex I) bolsters the cytotoxic activity of effector CD8+ T cells [25,26]. Mitochondrial metabolism promotes CD8+ T cell effector expansion via mitochondrial ROS-dependent NFAT activation [27], and mitochondrial translation maintains the cytolytic function of effector CD8+ T cells by enabling synthesis of cytosolic proteins such as granzyme B and perforin [28]. Therefore, mitochondria shape CD8+ T cell effector function.

Compared to effector cells, memory CD8+ T cells have increased mitochondrial content and spare respiratory capacity (SRC) that are critical for rapid proliferation and survival upon antigen recall [29,30]. Accordingly, memory CD8+ T cells have a fused mitochondrial network with densely packed cristae that support enhanced OXPHOS, while effector cells have more punctate mitochondria with looser cristae that enable them to better engage glycolysis [31]. Mitochondrial cardiolipin synthesis maintains mitochondrial fitness in circulating memory CD8+ T cells [32] and poises CD8+ tissue-resident memory (TRM) cells for activation [33]. CRISPR-based functional perturbation screens revealed that mitochondrial translation and ubiquinone synthesis underlie CD8+ TRM formation and functional responses against tumors [34,35], establishing the central importance of mitochondria for CD8+ T cell memory responses.

Finally, the effector function and lineage stability of CD4+ Foxp3+ Tregs are dependent on mitochondrial respiration (Figure 2D). Impaired ETC activity in Tregs inhibits the generation of suppressive effector Tregs (eTregs) that maintain immune tolerance in lymphoid and nonlymphoid tissues [36–38]. mTORC1 [36,39], MYC [40], and LKB1 [41,42] signaling enforces mitochondrial function in Tregs. Therefore, mitochondrial metabolism sustains Treg suppressive function to enforce immune homeostasis.

sec.title: Mitochondrial fitness combats T cell dysfunction
sec.p: During chronic infection or cancer, chronic antigen stimulation promotes T cell exhaustion and a metabolic shift from OXPHOS to glycolysis [43]. CD8+ T cell differentiation occurs from stem-like precursors of exhausted T (Tpex) cells to terminally exhausted (Tex) cells via a transitory effector-like Tex state [44]. The accumulation of dysfunctional mitochondria facilitates terminal exhaustion by impairing stem-like T cell expansion [45] or inciting epigenetic reprogramming [46], and is accompanied by HIF-1α-mediated metabolic reprogramming towards glycolysis due to the accumulation of ROS [47]. Further, acetyl-CoA generated from mitochondria-derived citrate contributes to terminal exhaustion programming through ACLY-KAT2A-mediated acetylation, while acetate-derived acetyl-CoA promotes stemness via the ACSS2-p300 acetyltransferase complex [48]. Beyond chronic stimulation, inhibitory molecules expressed by T cells can also alter mitochondrial dynamics or metabolism. For example, PD-1 signaling in CD8+ T cells decreases Drp1-driven mitochondrial fission, thereby impairing T cell proliferation [46,49], while CTLA-4 signaling increases OXPHOS in CD4+ T cells, thereby inhibiting their clonal expansion and egress from the lymph node to tumor [50]. Therefore, mitochondrial fitness helps combat T cell dysfunction in response to chronic antigen or inhibitory receptor stimulation.

sec.title: Lysosome-directed metabolism and fitness in T cell function
sec.p: Transportation of cytosolic components to the lysosome via non-selective macroautophagy (autophagy hereafter) and substrate-specific selective autophagy constitutes a major catabolic process in T cells responding to nutrient deprivation or cellular stress. This section discusses autophagy-dependent and -independent roles of lysosomes in T cell homeostasis and function (Figure 3).

sec.title: Lysosomes in T cell activation and differentiation
sec.p: Autophagy is dynamically regulated in T cell states, with naïve and memory CD8+ T cells exhibiting increased autophagy flux relative to effector CD8+ T cells. Naïve CD8+ T cells require autophagy to maintain expression of the lymphoid tissue homing receptor CD62L and increase mitophagy, which augments their survival by increasing expression of the anti-apoptotic protein MCL-1 (Figure 3A) [51]. Likewise, memory CD8+ T cells have reduced amino acid import and enhance autophagy flux to support their biosynthetic needs (Figure 3B) [51]. Accordingly, autophagy inhibition compromises recall responses in CD8+ and CD4+ T cells (Figure 3B) [52], and temporal analysis showed that autophagy flux is low during the activation and early effector stages, but increases immediately before the contraction phase [53]. Autophagy also regulates intratumoral CD8+ T cell metabolism and function. High levels of extracellular potassium in the TME perturb nutrient uptake by CD8+ T cells and induce a starvation-like state, resulting in elevated autophagy flux that is associated with increased T cell stemness but reduced effector function [54]. Conversely, autophagy inhibition via loss of Atg5 enhances glucose metabolism in CD8+ T cells while reducing S-adenosylmethionine levels, thereby decreasing histone H3K27 trimethylation to support transcriptional programming for intratumoral effector memory CD8+ T cell generation [55]. Therefore, autophagy has subset-dependent effects on T cell metabolism and function.

Beyond modulating memory and intratumoral CD8+ T cell responses, autophagy is essential to maintain mitochondrial respiration and prevent anergy during CD4+ T cell activation [56]. Tregs have increased autophagosome formation compared to conventional CD4+ T cells [57], which supports their functional and metabolic fitness and survival (Figure 3C) [57–59]. TRAFIP3-mediated inhibition of mTORC1, a negative regulator of autophagy, enhances Treg suppressive function [60], although autophagy inhibition reciprocally increases mTORC1 in Tregs (Figure 3C) [57]. However, inhibiting autophagy may be an effective intervention for overcoming the immunosuppressive effects of intratumoral Tregs on antitumor immunity by decreasing their abundance in the tumor microenvironment (TME) [57–59]. Therefore, autophagy has cell type- and tissue-specific effects on T cell responses.

T cells also engage selective autophagy, which promotes T cell activation by degrading Itch and RCAN1, two negative regulators of TCR signaling [61], and supports activated T cell survival and proliferation by interplaying with mTORC1 signaling via TAX1BP1-dependent generation of l-cysteine (Figure 3D) [62]. Selective autophagy also alters the differentiation trajectory of CD4+ T cell subsets [63] and increases effector memory CD8+ T cell differentiation via mitophagy (Figure 3B) [64], indicating that the clearance of specific cargos plays an important role in T cell fate and function. Beyond marking damaged mitochondria for clearance, the mitophagy adaptors Parkin and Nix are essential to suppress VDAC1-dependent apoptosis and ROS-mediated ferroptosis in memory CD8+ T cells, respectively (Figure 3B) [65], highlighting multiple roles for selective autophagy in T cell biology.

Besides circulatory T cell populations, lysosomal processes also support functional T cell adaptation to tissue microenvironments. Human liver-resident T cells have increased autophagy flux corresponding to enhanced expression of tissue-homing or retention markers [66]. Ablation of Flcn or Rag GTPases, amino acid-dependent negative regulators of TFEB-coordinated lysosome biogenesis [6], facilitates enhanced T cell migration to and CD8+ TRM differentiation in the small intestine to protect from intestinal infection (Figure 3B) [35]. As intestinal CD8+ TRM cells are enriched for lysosomes [33], these results indicate that lysosome-mediated nutrient sensing fosters tissue adaptation. Future investigation is warranted to fully understand the tissue-specific and temporal signals that lysosomes coordinate for CD8+ TRM migration and differentiation.

Beyond autophagy, lysosomes orchestrate lipolysis in T cells via the lipid hydrolase lysosomal acid lipase (LAL) (Figure 3B), which generates free fatty acids and cholesterol that can fuel mitochondrial respiration [67]. Enhancing LAL-mediated lipolysis enables memory CD8+ T cell survival and recall responses [30]. Conversely, LAL-deficient T cells undergo metabolic reprogramming from fatty acid catabolism to glycolysis, which corresponds to increased T cell anergy in a mouse model of graft-versus-host disease [68]. Therefore, both autophagy-dependent and -independent lysosome-directed metabolism influence T cell fate and function.

sec.title: Organelles as signaling platforms in T cell biology
sec.p: Mitochondria and lysosomes mediate bidirectional metabolic signaling in T cells [2]. This section summarizes how mitochondria and lysosomes serve as platforms to integrate and regulate metabolic signaling processes in T cells (Figure 4A,B).

sec.title: Mitochondria and lysosomes integrate extracellular cues for functional adaptation
sec.p: Extracellular immune signals derived from co-stimulatory or cytokine receptors reprogram metabolism for T cell functional adaptation [1] (Figure 1). For example, CD28 co-stimulation enhances memory CD8+ T cell programming by transiently inhibiting miR-33 to promote mitochondrial cristae remodeling and increase SRC [69]. In CD8+ T cells, 4–1BB co-stimulatory receptor engagement enhances PGC1α-dependent mitochondrial fusion and biogenesis, and synergizes with anti-PD-1 therapy to improve antitumor immune responses [70]. Conversely, the cytokine Meteorin-like promotes intratumoral CD8+ T cell hypofunction by inducing mitochondrial dysfunction [71]. In CD4+ T cells, cytokine stimulation with IL-6 increases MMP and triggers calcium flux into mitochondria, thereby increasing in vivo migratory capacity [72]. Moreover, TNF-α derived from naïve human CD4+ T cells upon activation stimulates Akt–mTOR signaling to promote maximal mitochondrial mass and metabolic rewiring for TH1 and TH17 differentiation [73]. Therefore, multiple immune signals converge on mitochondria to affect T cell biology.

Beyond immune signals 1–3, nutrients serve as signal 4 for T cell activation and differentiation (Figures 1 and 4A) [74]. In particular, nutrient transport and sensing, together with nutrient-induced signal transduction at lysosomes, are important to license mTORC1 activity and metabolic rewiring in T cells (Figure 4A) [74,75]. Besides impeding mTORC1 activation [74], glucose restriction also activates the AMPK–SENP1–Sirt3 axis to promote OXPHOS, mitochondrial fusion, and memory T cell formation [76]. Nutrients also impact CD8+ TRM generation [74]. For example, dietary cholesterol and amino acids influence CD8+ TRM formation through modulating SREBP2 and TFEB activity, respectively [34,35]. In nonimmune cells, the presence of cholesterol at the lysosomal membrane both recruits and activates mTORC1 through distinct pathways mediated by the GPCR-like protein LYCHOS [77] or the transmembrane SLC38A9-NPC1 complex [78], indicating that the lysosome serves as a sensor of nutrients beyond amino acids. Investigating these molecules and identifying other lysosome-mediated nutrient sensing and signaling functions in T cells will enhance our understanding of nutrient-dependent regulation of T cell fate and function [74].

Microenvironment-specific nutrients and metabolic signals can also alter T cell function. Intestinal CD8+ T cells have increased mitochondrial depolarization due to gut-derived prostaglandin E2 (PGE2); consequently, these cells increase autophagy and glutathione-dependent redox for functional adaptation to PGE2 [79]. In the TME, long-term exposure to acidic pH reduces one-carbon metabolism and promotes stemness-related programming in intratumoral CD8+ T cells [80], whereas hypoxia exacerbates chronic antigen-driven mitochondrial stress and CD8+ T cell exhaustion [81]. Moreover, while PTPMT1-dependent mitochondrial oxidation of glucose-derived pyruvate supports intratumoral effector CD8+ T cell function [82], CD8+ T cells can adapt to use alternative nutrients when glucose is limited, such as inosine [83] or lipids [84]. Lactate has pH-dependent effects on CD8+ T cells: pH-neutral sodium lactate increases antitumor immunity and augments T cell stemness by inhibiting histone deacetylation at the Tcf7 locus [85], while lactate from the acidified TME inhibits effector function and contributes to metabolic dysfunction mediated by the transporter MCT11, which is selectively upregulated in exhausted CD8+ T cells in response to chronic antigen stimulation [86]. Mechanistically, tumor-derived lactate rewires pyruvate metabolism by inhibiting pyruvate carboxylase-mediated generation of TCA cycle intermediates, thereby reducing autocrine signaling through the succinate receptor and compromising CD8+ T cell cytotoxicity [87]. Lactate availability in the TME also influences Treg responses. Lactate import by MCT1 supports intratumoral Treg proliferation and suppressive function by fueling the TCA cycle and gluconeogenic metabolism, allowing Tregs to thrive in glucose-depleted environments like the TME [88]. In human Tregs, lactate regulates mitochondrial metabolism by XBP1-mediated transcription of MGAT1, which is subsequently translocated into mitochondria to increase N-glycosylation events that promote OXPHOS [89]. Together, mitochondria integrate extracellular cues to regulate T cell metabolic and functional adaptation.

sec.title: Mitochondria and lysosomes shape intracellular signaling
sec.p: Mitochondria and lysosomes regulate mTORC1- and AMPK-mediated kinase signaling, thereby contributing to T cell metabolic adaptation. TCR-mediated mTORC1 activation is induced and sustained by amino acids and GTPases RagA/B and Rheb at the lysosome (Figure 4A) [90,91], whereas mTORC1 recruitment to and activation at the lysosome are negatively regulated by the lysosomal protein NKG7 [92]. mTORC1 signaling coordinates multiple metabolic processes that orchestrate T cell quiescence exit, including glycolysis, lipid synthesis, and OXPHOS [2]. For example, Tregs have elevated mTORC1 activity compared to naïve T cells, which enhances mitochondrial metabolism and facilitates the expression of ICOS and CTLA-4 to establish suppressive function [36,39]. Nutrient deprivation inhibits mTORC1 signaling and induces activation of the energy sensor AMPK (Figure 4A), which promotes mitochondrial fitness essential for long-term T cell proliferation [93] and accumulation or persistence of central [76] and effector [93] memory T cell subsets. AMPK also supports glutamine-dependent mitochondrial metabolism and T cell survival during glucose restriction [94]. Therefore, mTORC1 and AMPK integrate nutrient cues to impact T cell functional adaptation.

Besides coordinating nutrient-dependent kinase signaling, a key function of mitochondrial metabolism is to generate metabolites that orchestrate transcriptional and epigenetic events (Figure 4B). For example, the transcription factors TFAM [36,37,95,96] and Eomes [97] regulate context-dependent functions of T cells and Tregs, partly by inducing transcriptional and epigenetic rewiring to enhance mitochondrial activity and support effector function. Specifically, TFAM prevents the development of proinflammatory CD4+ T cell subsets by regulating the intracellular NAD+/NADH ratio to maintain lysosomal homeostasis (Figure 4A) [95]. TFAM also prevents premature senescence induced by type 1 cytokines [96] and contributes to the maintenance of immune tolerance by Tregs [36,37]. Conversely, Eomes is associated with pathogenic CD4+ T cell responses that heighten inflammation in the central nervous system [97]. Moreover, acetyl-CoA derived from citrate by ACLY, or from acetate by ACSS2 in the context of ACLY deficiency, promotes mitochondrial respiration and chromatin accessibility of the Ifng and Gzmb loci, thereby enhancing effector CD8+ T cell function in response to acute viral infection; these findings reveal that both citrate- and acetate-derived acetyl-CoA pools serve largely redundant roles in regulating effector CD8+ T cell responses [98]. In contrast, ACLY provokes terminal exhaustion while ACSS2 supports stemness in CD8+ Tex cells as described in the preceding text [48], suggesting context-dependent contributions of ACLY and ACSS2 to CD8+ T cell programming. Acetyl-CoA also facilitates enrichment of acetylated H3K9 at the Ifng promoter to support intratumoral effector CD8+ T cell function, which is reduced upon ACLY inhibitor treatment [54]. In CD8+ T cells, the transcription factor Bhlhe40 facilitates the production of TCA metabolites and histone acetylation of effector gene loci necessary for CD8+ TRM cell formation and function, which may be mediated in part by ACLY [99]. Acetyl-CoA production by ACLY is also associated with maintenance of CD4+ T cell effector functions, including IFN-γ production by TH1 cells [21] and IL-17 production downstream of GLUT3-dependent glucose metabolism in TH17 cells [100]. Mitochondrial one-carbon metabolism is upregulated and promotes cell survival during naïve CD4+ T cell activation [14,15], and also generates S-adenosylmethionine that is the substrate for histone methylation reactions associated with epigenetic regulation (Figure 4B) [2]. Besides mitochondrial metabolism, polyamine metabolism, regulated by the enzymes ODC1 and SAT1, governs CD4+ T cell subset fidelity via transcriptional and epigenetic effects [101,102] or elF5A hypusination [102]. Therefore, multiple metabolic mechanisms regulate transcriptional and epigenetic rewiring in T cells. Identifying mechanisms for increasing mitochondria–nuclear crosstalk, such as via mitochondrial metabolites, may be permissive to tune T cell functional programming.

Nutrient signaling at lysosomes also contributes to transcriptional remodeling mediated by TFEB (Figure 4A). Recent studies highlight that Treg-specific loss of TFEB (via CRISPR–Cas9 gene targeting) reduces Treg accumulation and causes mitochondrial dysfunction [103]. In contrast, hyperactivation of TFEB upon Flcn deletion induces CD8+ TRM differentiation in the small intestine by promoting CCR9-mediated migration and TGF-β signaling (Figure 3B) [35], although TFEB hyperactivation in cDC1 cells inhibits glutamine-mediated licensing of intratumoral CD8+ T cells [104]. Beyond transcription, lysosomal function can affect epigenetic modifications that alter T cell metabolism. For example, cancer cell-derived lactate induces histone lysine lactylation in intratumoral CD8+ T cells, increasing lysosomal acidification and impeding MCT1-dependent lactate transport to the mitochondria for oxidative metabolism; such effects are rectified by lithium carbonate that induces TFEB-dependent LDHB expression necessary for lactate oxidation into pyruvate [105]. Moreover, delivery of nuclear SIRT1 to lysosomes by selective autophagy promotes senescence due to dysregulation of histone deacetylation [106], thereby supporting lysosome–epigenome crosstalk in T cell function. Therefore, mitochondria and lysosomes integrate nutrient-mediated intracellular signaling cues to establish metabolic control of transcriptional and epigenetic programming.

sec.title: Organelle crosstalk in T cells
sec.p: Organelle–organelle membrane contact sites regulate organelle communication. For example, endoplasmic reticulum (ER)-derived calcium influx into mitochondria via mitochondria–ER contact sites (MERCs) regulates T cell homeostasis and function (Figure 4C). During thymocyte maturation, GRP75 promotes the survival and transition of DN3 thymocytes to the DN4 stage via MERCs by bridging interactions between IP3R (on ER) and VDAC1 (on outer mitochondrial membrane; OMM) [107]. ER-derived calcium flux into the mitochondria is partly regulated by phosphoenolpyruvate that blocks SERCA-mediated calcium uptake by the ER [108]. MERCs, mediated by MFN2 on the OMM and SERCA2 on the ER, support the proliferation and cytotoxicity of CD8+ T cells in mouse syngeneic tumor models [109]. As such, transient enrichment of MERCs (e.g., by increasing membrane fluidity [110]) represents a useful strategy for elevating effector T cell function in the TME.

Regulation of interorganelle communication must remain intact, as both mitochondrial calcium overload and reduced calcium influx can negatively affect mitochondrial function and T cell metabolism. A genome-wide CRISPR screen in Jurkat T cells revealed that the ER transmembrane protein VMP1 regulates store-operated calcium entry by mediating calcium efflux from the ER, thereby preventing mitochondrial calcium overload and maintaining T cell survival [111]. Lysosomes are emerging as an additional regulator of mitochondrial calcium levels, and a recent study in NK cells revealed that lysosomes regulate mitochondrial calcium influx through the calcium channel TRPML1, indicating an essential role for mitochondria–lysosome crosstalk in cellular fitness [112]. Although mitochondria–lysosome interactions are not yet described in T cells, future studies should explore roles for mitochondria–lysosome contact sites and other types of organelle–organelle crosstalk in T cell fitness.

Organelle crosstalk is also facilitated by extracellular cues that promote the simultaneous activation of multiple intracellular pathways. For example, CD2 co-stimulation of CD8+ T cells promotes AMPK localization to lysosomes, where AMPK mediates lytic granule polarization towards the immune synapse and enhances cytotoxicity [113]. Together, these studies suggest that multiple layers of regulation on organelle contact sites are required to maintain optimal T cell function. Beyond intracellular organelle crosstalk, emerging studies show that organelles facilitate communication between cells; the functional consequences of intercellular mitochondria transfer are discussed in Box 1.

sec.title: Mitochondria and lysosomes in immune-mediated diseases
sec.p: The functional interdependence of mitochondrial and lysosomal activity extends to disease development and progression [114]. For example, autophagy is rapidly induced during the early transition phase of effector to memory CD8+ T cell differentiation during LCMV (both Armstrong and clone 13 strains) infection, and promotes mitochondria–lysosome crosstalk to maintain memory T cell metabolism [53]. Autophagy controls oxidative stress in hypoxic tissues, and Atg5-deficient CD8+ T cells have increased expression of proapoptotic p53 that leads to cell death due to ROS accumulation [115]. Redox balance is an essential mediator of T cell function. Accordingly, reduced production of the antioxidant glutathione by genetic ablation of the catalytic subunit Gclc promotes the accumulation of ROS and mitochondrial dysfunction in intestinal TH17 cells, leading to impaired IL-22 production that is necessary for intestinal tissue integrity and clearance of Citrobacter rodentium infection [116]. Likewise, loss of Opa1 compromises the maintenance of tissue-resident TH17 cells that prevent intestinal inflammation arising from commensal pathogens [22]. The contribution of lysosomes or autophagy to glutathione-mediated redox balance or control of intestinal pathogens requires further investigation.

Environmental stressors have context-dependent effects on mitochondria- or lysosome-mediated T cell responses. For example, febrile temperatures induced by infection augment mitochondrial gene transcription and enhance CD8+ T cell effector function [117]. Nutrient deprivation is another source of environmental stress and is commonly associated with the immunosuppressive TME, leading to metabolic dysfunction in intratumoral T cell populations and tumor immune evasion [118]. Consequently, aberrant metabolic reprogramming in the TME can contribute to CD8+ T cell exhaustion as discussed in the preceding text [43,45,46,48,54,81]. The TME also compromises the metabolic adaptation of conventional CD4+ T cells by promoting Treg-mediated inhibition of CD4+ T cell glycolytic metabolism via CTLA-4 [50]. Since Tregs are a frequent barrier to antitumor immunity [118], using bimodal therapeutic strategies that improve conventional T cell function while simultaneously reducing Treg-mediated immunosuppression is promising. To this end, introducing mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) mutations that support effector T cell metabolism while suppressing Treg function [119] or inhibiting autophagy to promote effector memory T cell differentiation [55] and reduce Treg accumulation in the TME [57–59] are intriguing options for enhancing antitumor immunity.

Mitochondrial and lysosomal alterations are also evident in autoimmunity. For example, in mice with experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis, the transcription factor Eomes enhances mitochondrial mass and oxidative metabolism that promotes the persistence and survival of highly inflammatory CD4+ Eomes+ T cells [97]. Similarly, in rheumatoid arthritis (RA), enhanced TNF-α secretion upon CD4+ T cell activation coordinates mitochondrial expansion and increases IL-17 and IFN-γ production associated with RA pathology [73]. Proinflammatory cytokines derived from T cells may induce microenvironmental metabolic changes that establish autoimmunity, such as the muscle damage and weakness mediated by IFN-γ-producing TH1 cells in Icos–/– nonobese diabetic mice [120]. During autoimmunity, Tregs exhibit mitochondrial oxidative stress that inhibits lysosomal function and restricts mitophagy, resulting in Treg dysfunction, activation of DNA damage response, and cell death [121]. Lymphocytes isolated from patients with autoimmune diseases have increased autophagy flux and mitochondrial activity, and inhibiting autophagy during CD4+ T cell activation induces long-lasting hyporesponsiveness and decreases the severity of autoimmunity by promoting T cell anergy [56]. Therefore, inhibiting mitochondrial function or altering mitochondria–lysosome crosstalk may be effective methods for controlling autoimmune diseases.

Beyond immune-mediated diseases, organelle dysfunction in T cells is also emerging in human inborn errors of immunity (IEIs) and metabolic diseases. A metabolic CRISPR screen showed that inactivating the IEI gene Bcl11b impairs the thymic differentiation and mitochondrial metabolism of T cells, explaining why patients with BCL11B mutations develop combined immunodeficiency with low T cell numbers [122]. Future studies should continue to explore the interplay between these diseases, organelles, and immunometabolism.

sec.title: Concluding remarks
sec.p: Mitochondria and lysosomes and their interplay with metabolism serve important roles in T cell fate and function, though many questions remain (see Outstanding questions). In particular, context (i.e., tissue or cell state)-specific functions of these organelles remain to be fully elucidated. Unbiased tools like single-cell CRISPR screens [123–126] or single-cell-level metabolic flux analysis (e.g., COMPASS [101] or SCENITH [127]) will provide additional mechanistic insight for such context specificity. Applying methods to model organelle contact sites [128] and developing more advanced imaging tools to better define organelle-directed metabolic rewiring with intra-tissue or subcellular resolution will enhance our understanding of organelle biology in T cells. Finally, future studies are warranted to identify or repurpose therapeutic agents to modify the activity of these organelles while limiting off-target effects (Table 1). Collectively, these studies will advance our ability to target these organelles to modulate T cell function to treat diseases.

caption.p: Signals 1–4 regulate T cell functional adaptation and instigate mitochondria-and lysosome-dependent metabolic reprogramming. Signals 1 (TCR binding to cognate antigen), 2 (co-stimulation; e.g., CD28 or 4–1BB), and 3 (cytokines; e.g., IL-2, IL-6, or IL-15) tune nutrient-dependent Signal 4 by altering the expression of nutrient transporters. Signal 4 reciprocally regulates Signals 1–3 by altering metabolic and signaling pathways. Together, these extracellular cues influence mitochondrial and lysosomal functions to induce metabolic rewiring and signaling events that support T cell functional adaptation in response to microenvironmental cues. Organelle crosstalk (e.g., between mitochondria and lysosomes) further supports metabolic reprogramming and context-specific functions.

caption.title: Mitochondrial metabolism influences T cell fate and function.
caption.p: (A) Oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS) and glycolysis are differentially regulated throughout thymic development. αβ T cells have increased OXPHOS over glycolysis at the double-negative 3 (DN3) stage, accompanied by mTORC1 activation and MYC expression. mTORC1 and MYC reciprocally activate one another to facilitate αβ T cell lineage commitment and inhibit γδ T cell differentiation. Mitochondrial pyruvate oxidation (mediated by mitochondrial pyruvate carrier; MPC1) is required at the β-selection, immature single-positive (ISP)-SP transition, and positive selection stages of development. (B) The electron transport chain (ETC) is essential for CD4+ T cell activation, effector function, and survival as indicated. Various inhibitors of ETC function are depicted. (C) Mitochondrial metabolism and dynamics regulate CD8+ T cell programming. Mitochondrial protein translation generates ETC components that are required to establish mitochondrial membrane potential (MMP) and effector T (TEFF) cell cytotoxic function. MMP induces reactive oxygen species (ROS) and is negatively regulated by MCJ, an inhibitor of ETC Complex I. MMP and ROS levels coordinate memory T (TMEM) versus TEFF responses, as decreased MMP/ROS promotes long-term TMEM survival and quiescence by reducing oxidative stress, while increased MMP/ROS promotes TEFF activation downstream of TCR stimulation. Opa1-mediated mitochondrial fusion increases OXPHOS to enhance TMEM generation, while Drp1-mediated mitochondrial fission increases glycolysis for TEFF cells. (D) Oxidative metabolism maintains regulatory T (Treg) cell functional fitness. TFAM induces mitochondrial gene expression that supports the synthesis of ETC components, while LKB1 and mTORC1 signaling promotes mitochondrial metabolism that fuels ETC function. Together with MYC activity, these processes increase OXPHOS and promote effector Treg (eTreg) cell activation to induce the expression of eTreg suppressive molecules (e.g., ICOS, CTLA-4, KLRG1, and IL-10).

caption.title: Autophagy is differentially regulated in T cell subsets.
caption.p: (A) Naïve T (TNAIVE) cells have increased autophagy flux that supports their survival and homeostasis. Upper: increased clearance of damaged mitochondria via Parkin- and Nix-mediated mitophagy enhances expression of antiapoptotic MCL-1, promoting TNAIVE survival and homeostasis. Lower: increased autophagy flux increases the generation of nutrients to support protein synthesis, including the adhesion receptor CD62L that supports TNAIVE trafficking in lymphoid tissues. (B) Lysosomal metabolism regulates memory T (TMEM) cell generation. TMEM cells have increased autophagy flux and lipolysis mediated by lysosomal acid lipase (LAL), which both generate substrates for mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS), enhancing TMEM recall responses and survival. Parkin- and Nix-mediated mitophagy inhibits apoptosis or ferroptosis and induces the recycling of mitochondrial metabolites to generate long-chain fatty acids (LCFAs) that are used as an energy source to promote effector memory T (TEM) cell generation. Nutrient-replete conditions suppress the activation of transcription factor TFEB that promotes lysosome biogenesis and CCR9-mediated trafficking of CD8+ T cells to the small intestine. (C) Lysosome-mediated metabolism promotes effector regulatory T (eTreg) cell function. TRAFIP3-mediated mTORC1 inhibition at the lysosome promotes autophagy flux, enhancing oxidative metabolism that supports eTreg maintenance and suppressive function. mTORC1 signaling negatively regulates autophagy and promotes glycolytic metabolism, which can impair Foxp3 expression and compromise Treg lineage stability. (D) Effector T (TEFF) cells maintain their activation status via selective autophagy. Selective autophagy, mediated by chaperone proteins such as TAX1BP1, promotes the degradation of Itch and RCAN1. Substrate degradation increases the generation of nutrients like L-cysteine that activate mTORC1 signaling and promote glycolytic metabolism, increasing TEFF proliferation and survival.

caption.title: Mitochondria and lysosomes are signaling platforms in T cells.
caption.p: (A) Lysosome-associated signaling coordinates nutrient cues and metabolic reprogramming. Nutrient-replete environments activate mTORC1-mediated anabolic metabolism via the lysosome-associated small G proteins RagA/B and Rheb and inhibit catabolic metabolism initiated by AMPK. Flcn and RagA/B inhibit TFEB-mediated lysosomal biogenesis under nutrient-replete conditions, while TFAM-dependent oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS) negatively regulates TFEB to maintain metabolic homeostasis. (B) Mitochondria-associated signaling processes regulate T cell transcriptional and epigenetic reprogramming. Mitochondrial reactive oxygen species (mROS), a byproduct of OXPHOS, activate the transcription factor NFAT to coordinate T cell activation and differentiation. Citrate-derived acetyl-CoA (generated by ACLY) promotes histone acetylation, while one-carbon (1C) metabolism mediated by MTHFD2 induces S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) expression that coordinates histone methylation. (C) Mitochondria-ER crosstalk is mediated by membrane contact sites called MERCs, which regulate calcium (Ca2+) influx into the mitochondria. MERCs are mediated by different molecules according to developmental stage. GRP75 bridges IP3R (ER) and VDAC1 (mitochondria) interactions to promote the transition of DN3 to DN4 thymocytes in the thymus, while SERCA2 (ER) and MFN2 (mitochondria) enhance the proliferation and cytotoxicity of TEFF cells in the periphery. VMP1 mediates store-operated calcium entry (SOCE) to prevent calcium overload in the mitochondria or the ER, thereby limiting calcium-induced mitochondria and ER stress.

boxed-text.p: Organelles, especially mitochondria and lysosomes, are crucial hubs orchestrating the metabolic fate and functional adaptation of T cells in response to different inflammatory insults or tissue microenvironments.
Beyond their bioenergetic and degradative functions, mitochondria and lysosomes coordinate extracellular and intracellular signaling cues to orchestrate T cell-mediated adaptive immunity.

Mitochondria and lysosomes regulate cell fate decisions via organelle crosstalk, and dysregulation of either mitochondrial or lysosomal fitness is frequently associated with dysfunction in the other organelle.
Aberrant mitochondrial or lysosomal function contributes to immune-mediated diseases and is a potential target for therapeutic intervention.

Cellular metabolism is a key regulator of T cell-mediated adaptive immunity. As central hubs for bioenergetic and biosynthetic reactions, mitochondria and lysosomes support T cell functional adaptation. These organelles also coordinate signaling processes that establish transcriptional and epigenetic programs in T cells, thereby contributing to adaptive immune responses. Therefore, tuning mitochondrial or lysosomal activity is a promising intervention to bolster T cell fitness or restore cellular homeostasis.

caption.title: Box 1. Intercellular mitochondrial transfer and T cell function

boxed-text.p: Recent work has shown that intercellular mitochondrial transfer can reinvigorate or hamper cellular metabolism and function in a context-dependent manner. Protrusions of F-actin, termed tunneling nanotubes (TNTs), mediate the transfer of mitochondria to and from T cells. The functional impact of intercellular mitochondria exchange is dependent on the direction of organelle transfer and the source of donor mitochondria. Talin-2-mediated mitochondrial transfer from bone marrow stromal cells invigorates CD8+ T cell cytotoxicity against mouse models of solid and hematological cancers [129], while Miro1-mediated transfer of mitochondria from CD8+ T cells to cancer cells augments cancer cell respiration and impairs T cell function [130]. Mitochondrial transfer has translational relevance, both for inhibiting cancer cell-mediated metabolic dysfunction in T cells and for reinvigorating aged, senescent T cells (Figure I). The transfer of cancer cell-derived mitochondria to CD8+ T cells causes endogenous mitochondria to accumulate mtDNA mutations and undergo mitophagy, while the cancer cell-derived mitochondria remain intact due to cotransfer of the deubiquitinase USP30 [131]. Conversely, transplantation of healthy mitochondria from young fibroblasts into aged CD4+ T cells reduces senescence by improving metabolic fitness, resulting in increased control of Mycobacterium tuberculosis or influenza A upon adoptive transfer into mice [132,133]. Mechanistically, mitochondrial transfer from mesenchymal stem/stromal cells (MSCs) enhances the apoptotic resistance of both native and engineered T cells by maintaining mitochondrial fitness and increasing cellular expression of antiapoptotic protein Bcl2 [134]. Beyond the contexts of cancer or infectious disease, organelle transfer may serve as a regulatory mechanism for controlling autoimmune or inflammatory responses, as mitochondrial transfer from MSCs to CD4+ T cells increases the accumulation of Foxp3+ Tregs [135]. While lysosomal transfer between T cells and other cell types has not been described, the functional effects would likely be similar to those observed with mitochondrial transfer. Specifically, transfer of functional lysosomes may enhance nutrient sensing and recycling, while transfer of dysfunctional lysosomes may compromise T cell metabolism and functional fitness. How intercellular organelle transfer beyond mitochondria shapes T cell immunometabolism will be important to explore.
